title: 114_hr4237
content: The "Protect America Act of 2015" grants the Attorney General the authority to deny firearm sales to known or suspected terrorists, requires information-sharing on their attempted purchases, and authorizes investigations into terrorists trying to buy firearms. The "Preventing Terrorists From Obtaining Firearms Act of 2015" amends Section 922(t) of title 18, United States Code, giving the Attorney General authority to take steps when notified of a firearm transfer request to a known or suspected terrorist, including confirming identity, notifying relevant agencies, and checking for ongoing terrorism investigations. The "Preventing Terrorists From Obtaining Firearms Act of 2015" allows the Attorney General to delay firearm transfers to suspected terrorists for up to 72 hours and file an emergency petition to prohibit the transfer if there is probable cause of terrorism involvement. The "Preventing Terrorists From Obtaining Firearms Act of 2015" defines a "known or suspected terrorist" as someone engaged in terrorism-related activities and allows the Attorney General to delay firearm transfers to such individuals for up to 72 hours. The Attorney General is granted authority to deny the sale, delivery, or transfer of explosives to known or suspected terrorists. Information-sharing is required for attempted explosives purchases by these individuals, and investigations are authorized for terrorists attempting to buy explosives. The "Preventing Terrorists From Obtaining Explosives Act of 2015" grants the Attorney General authority to deny explosives permits to known or suspected terrorists. Further steps must be taken to confirm the identity and potential terrorist ties of applicants. The Attorney General can notify law enforcement or intelligence agencies about applicants, delay approval for up to 90 days, and initiate terrorism investigations if needed under the "Preventing Terrorists From Obtaining Explosives Act of 2015." The "Preventing Terrorists From Obtaining Explosives Act of 2015" allows for emergency petitions to be filed in court to prevent approval of applications or issuance of clearance if there is probable cause of terrorism involvement. Petitions can only be granted after a hearing where the individual has notice and the opportunity to participate with counsel. The term "known or suspected terrorist" is defined in this subsection. The "Preventing Terrorists From Obtaining Explosives Act of 2015" allows emergency petitions to prevent approval of applications if there is probable cause of terrorism involvement. The term "known or suspected terrorist" is defined as a person engaged in conduct related to terrorism or providing material support. The "Preventing Terrorists From Obtaining Explosives Act of 2015" includes a sunset provision for the amendments made by sections 2 and 3, which will expire after a 3-year period from the enactment of the Act. Additionally, the Act requires reports to Congress. The Attorney General must submit a report to Congress within 18 months to 3 years after the enactment of the Act on petitions and court orders related to domestic and international terrorism, including the number of petitions filed, orders granted, denials, arrests made, and the citizenship status of the individuals involved. The Attorney General must report to Congress on petitions and court orders related to terrorism, including outcomes of deportation proceedings and multiple petitions filed against individuals. Within 90 days of this Act, the Attorney General must review and correct the terrorist watch list and no-fly list to remove any individuals erroneously listed or not suspected terrorists. A report detailing these actions must be submitted to Congress.
